titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Brown vs. Board of Education Collection
Brown vs. Board of Education Collection
titlestmt.author: compiled by Peter Bartucca

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 07:26

did.unittitle: Brown vs. Board of Education collection

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: Interview notes, correspondence, clippings, copies of court transcripts and briefs assembled by Richard Kluger for his book, Simple Justice: Brown vs. Board of Education . Kluger's interview notes, taken either in person or by mail, with over one hundred people make up the core of the collection. Especially full materials are available for Alexander Bickel, Hugo L. Black, Esther Brown, Linda Brown, John W. Davis, Felix Frankfurter, William H. Hastie, Kenneth B. Clark, Charles H. Houston, Thurgood Marshall, William H. Rehnquist, and Earl Warren. Kluger's copies of the correspondence files of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) relating to this case are also included in the collection, as are two unpublished manuscripts by Phyllis Kluger: an article, "A Short History of Education in the United States," and a book, A Long History of Negro Education .

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Brown vs. Board of Education Collection (MS 759). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: Additional information not yet available in the online version of the finding aid exists in the repository. Contact Manuscripts and Archives for assistance.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Richard Kluger Papers (MS 1443). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in four series, maintaining Kruger's original organization of his research files: I. Subject Files. II. NAACP Legal Defense Fund Correspondence. III. Court Transcripts and Law Review Articles. IV. Sources and Additional Research Materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Brown vs. Board of Education Collection consists of the research materials used by Richard Kluger in the preparation of his book,Simple Justice: Brown vs. Board of Education(1976). The book is a history of the Supreme Court decision in that case and the events, social and legal, which preceded it. The collection itself is comprised of interview notes, some correspondence, newspaper and magazine articles, and a large amount of photocopied material such as court transcripts, contemporary newspaper and magazine articles and correspondence from the files of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund. The great strengths of the collection lie in the fact that Kluger has gathered together a great deal of primary source material in the form of interviews with many of the central figures involved in the case. In addition, there are photocopies of correspondence and court transcripts. Subsequent researchers will be greatly aided by the availability of this material in one location.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

controlaccess.persname: Du Bois, W. E. B. (William Edward Burghardt), 1868-1963

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is arranged in two sections: Correspondence, Interviews and Individual Files; and Place and Topic Files. The first section consists of letters written in response to Kluger's inquiries; interview notes, both typed and handwritten; newspaper clippings; magazine articles; and photocopies of newspaper and magazine articles. The folders are arranged alphabetically by individual. The materials they contain have been treated as subject material because Kluger used them that way, and their value would be greatly diminished if they were to be removed, or rearranged by type of material.

The interview notes are among the most valuable materials in the collection. These interviews with Supreme Court Justices, their clerks, NAACP lawyers and other prominent individuals in these cases provide the researcher with a personal view of the individuals interviewed, the events of which they were a part, a view which is not available through other sources. The researcher should recognize, however, that these are notes of interviews and not question and answer transcripts.

Kluger states in "Sources and Acknowledgements" that some of the interviews were conducted by correspondence; the individuals interviewed in this way are indicated by the notation (C) on his list of "Interviews and Correspondence" contained in the "Sources and Acknowledgements" folder. Fewer than half of the folders contain original correspondence but valuable information can be found in the correspondence of those individuals whom Kluger interviewed by mail. Unfortunately, with very few exceptions, the collection does not contain copies of Kluger's original letters, and in some cases the replies alone may not provide sufficient information for the researcher to judge their importance.

Significant information can be obtained from the following individual folders: Thurgood Marshall, Earl Warren, Charles H. Houston, William H. Hastie, Kenneth B. Clark, John W. Davis, Linda Brown, Felix Frankfurter, Hugo L. Black, Alexander Bickel, William H. Rehnquist and Esther Brown.

The second section consists of printed and photocopied material from newspapers, magazines and books as well as travel brochures and maps. The alphabetically arranged folders contain background information on the locations where the various cases originated and organizations and subjects such as the NAACP and Desegregation.

Jackson, Robert H., and William E. Jackson

"Adolescent Negro Education in Delaware," by George R. Miller, Jr.
South Carolina - Clarendon County supplementary data

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists entirely of photocopies or carbon copies of correspondence from the files of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund. The correspondence is arranged roughly in chronological order and has been numbered by Kluger as a key to a descriptive list which precedes the correspondence. The correspondence itself is very valuable to the researcher because it outlines the legal strategy employed by the NAACP in its fight to end segregation in the public school systems in the United States.

did.unittitle: Court Transcripts and Law Review Articles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists largely of photocopied transcripts and briefs; some official transcripts; a book; two papers by individuals other than Kluger, which provide background information; and three folders of Law Review articles dealing with segregation. Kluger states in "Sources and Acknowledgements" that these transcripts and briefs were the "most basic" materials in his research and that "assembling the legal record in the lower courts was a considerable project in itself." The researcher is saved a great deal of time and effort by having these transcripts and briefs collected together in this series.

did.unittitle: Brown : Kansas and U.S. government brief
"The Background of the Abandonment of Reconstruction" by C. Vann Woodward
School Segregation Cases: Proposed Appendix to Appelants' Briefs by Howard Jay Graham

unittitle.title: Davis vs. County School Board of Prince Edward County, Virginia

did.unittitle: Sweatt, other pre-Brown decisions, and chronology of civil rights cases

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes a section from Kluger's book, "Sources and Acknowledgements," which calls attention to the relative importance of the different materials in the collection. It also provides the researcher with a list of interviewees; the date or dates on which they were interviewed and their relationship to the case; a research bibliography; a table of cases cited; and chapter notes to the book. The second section of the series contains "A Short History of Education in the United States" and A Long History of Negro Education, both by Phyllis Kluger. The final section of the series contains two folders of photocopied journal articles discussing legal, social and historic aspects of the segregation cases.
